title: Cinque Terre Points of Interest - What to See

seo.title: Cinque Terre Points of Interest 2025 | Must-See Attractions
seo.description: Discover the top attractions in Cinque Terre. Historic churches, castles, viewpoints, hidden gems, and must-see landmarks in all five villages.

body.title: Points of Interest
body.subtitle: Medieval castles, historic churches, spectacular viewpoints, and hidden gems await in every village. Discover the landmarks and attractions that make Cinque Terre a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

body.title: Must-See Landmarks
body.subtitle: The defining sights of each village.

features.title: Santa Margherita d'Antiochia
features.description: Vernazza's iconic striped church overlooking the harbor. 14th-century gem with octagonal bell tower visible from the sea.

features.title: Doria Castle
features.description: Vernazza's medieval fortress offers panoramic views from its tower. Climb for the best perspective of the harbor below.

features.title: The Giant (Il Gigante)
features.description: Monterosso's 14-meter Neptune statue carved into the cliff. Damaged in WWII but still impressive.

features.title: Manarola Viewpoint
features.description: The world-famous view of colorful houses cascading to the sea. Best at sunset from the cemetery cliff.

features.title: Lardarina Staircase
features.description: Corniglia's famous 382-step staircase from the train station. A rite of passage for Cinque Terre visitors.

features.title: Aurora Tower
features.description: Monterosso's medieval tower in the old town. Once part of the village defense system.

body.title: Beyond the Famous Sights
body.subtitle: Lesser-known treasures worth discovering
body.content: **Sanctuary Trails** lead to hillside churches with panoramic views that few tourists visit. **Nessun Dorma** in Manarola offers the best sunset terrace. **Guvano Beach** was once a nudist haven (now harder to access). **Corniglia's vineyards** offer wine tastings with views. **San Pietro Church** in Corniglia dates to the 14th century. Explore the narrow **caruggi** (alleys) to discover authentic village life.

items.question: Are the churches free to enter?
items.answer: Yes, most churches are free. Donations appreciated. Dress modestly (no bare shoulders or short shorts). Check opening hours as they vary.

items.question: How much is the Doria Castle?
items.answer: €2 entry fee to climb the tower. Worth it for the views over Vernazza harbor. Open daily in season, reduced hours in winter.

items.question: What's the best viewpoint?
items.answer: Manarola's sunset viewpoint is most famous. Vernazza's Doria Castle and the Blue Trail between villages offer spectacular panoramas too.

items.question: Are attractions wheelchair accessible?
items.answer: Unfortunately, most attractions involve stairs and uneven terrain. The villages are built into cliffs. Limited accessibility is a reality here.

items.question: What's worth seeing in each village?
items.answer: Monterosso: Giant statue, old town, beach. Vernazza: harbor, castle, church. Corniglia: vineyards, panorama. Manarola: viewpoint, harbor. Riomaggiore: castle, street art.

items.question: How do I find hidden gems?
items.answer: Wander the back alleys, climb above the main streets, and explore early morning or evening when day-trippers leave. Ask locals for recommendations.
